name: Judea Pearl
background: Israeli-American computer scientist and philosopher (born 1936). Professor at UCLA, director of Cognitive Systems Laboratory. Pioneer of Bayesian networks and probabilistic AI. Developed structural causal models and do-calculus for causal inference. Turing Award 2011 for probabilistic and causal reasoning. Author of 'Causality' and 'The Book of Why'. Father of journalist Daniel Pearl.

principles.name: Bayesian Networks
principles.description: Directed acyclic graphs (DAGs) representing joint distributions via conditional independencies. Enables efficient probabilistic inference via belief propagation.
principles.falsification: When bayesian networks leads to worse outcomes than alternatives

principles.name: Causal Ladder (Rung 1: Association)
principles.description: Seeing patterns in data via conditional probabilities. P(Y|X) answers 'How does seeing X change belief in Y?' Foundation of statistics but limited to correlations.
principles.falsification: When causal ladder (rung 1: association) leads to worse outcomes than alternatives

principles.name: Causal Ladder (Rung 2: Intervention)
principles.description: Do-operator for actions: P(Y|do(X)). Answers 'What if I do X?' Requires causal graph to distinguish intervention from conditioning.
principles.falsification: When causal ladder (rung 2: intervention) leads to worse outcomes than alternatives

principles.name: Causal Ladder (Rung 3: Counterfactuals)
principles.description: Imagining alternate realities: P(Y_x | X=x'). Answers 'Was X the cause of Y?' or 'What if I had acted differently?' Highest level of causal reasoning.
principles.falsification: When causal ladder (rung 3: counterfactuals) leads to worse outcomes than alternatives
